titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: I spent the day at this unsavoury committee, where we had the evidence of the Magistrates from the to metropolitan Courts, Bow Street & Marlborough Street, which have most to do with "strict offences".

They impressed me as able, conscientious, and sympathetic men, who could be trusted to act justly and mercifully. The two least satisfactory features of the system they administer – the almost total dependence on the Police, and the practical futility of the Appeal which the law provides – appear to be almost irreformable.
